Fig. 1 In-house designed HTE system for catalyst testing utilized to evaluate ETB catalysts. The numbers correspond to specific unit: 1) EtOH gasification unit, 2) gas flow distributer, 3) reaction tubes, 4) electric furnace, 5) autosampler, 6) QMS, 7) exhaust system, and 8) data analysis. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Flow and temperature program employed for the catalyst testing. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Evolution of the catalysts in GA. a) The average performance of 20 catalysts in each generation, and b) the performance of the best catalyst in each generation, excluding the elites, are plotted against the generation. Blue triangle: EtOH conversion; green inverted triangle: BD yield; yellow tilted triangle: BD selectivity; black square: ethylene yield; red circle: AcH yield; purple rhombus: butene yield. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Elemental distribution represented by stacked area charts: a) generation-wise average and b) top 20 catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Temperature dependence of the EtOH conversion and product yields at the P EtOH / P Ar ratio of 0.09 for the top 20 catalysts. Note that the EtOH conversion at the lowest temperature was overestimated due to the bed wetting process. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Feature importance analysis based on SHAP values. In a), the mean absolute SHAP values are used to show the global feature importance. In b), the local feature importance is presented to illustrate the direction of the relationship between explanatory and target variables. The explanatory variables represent the loading amounts of individual elements in mmol, while the target variable is the BD yield. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Network visualization for the role of the elements in the ETB catalysis. Nodes representing the individual elements and performance metrics in ETB are linked according to the Shapley’s feature importance. The edge thickness relates to the magnitude of the Shapley’s feature importance. The edge color reflects the direction of the impact, where green and blue correspond to positive and negative impacts, respectively. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Network visualization of multi-element catalyst design for the ETB catalysis. Nodes represent class labels corresponding to the loading amount of the individual elements as well as the BD yield (pink: high, green: medium, and blue: low). The association between the loading amount and the BD yield was derived by analyzing the 276 catalysts obtained in GA. Fig. 8 Scheme 1 Toussaint-Kagan pathway for EtOH to BD conversion [27]. Scheme 1 Exploration of ethanol-to-butadiene catalysts by high-throughput experimentation and machine learning Tejkiran P. Manchan Data curation Panitha Phulkerd Data curation Patchanee Chammingkwan Toshiaki Taniike Conceptualization Methodology Visualization Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources ⁎ Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 1–1 Asahidai, Nomi, Ishikawa 923-1292, Japan Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology 1–1 Asahidai, Nomi Ishikawa 923-1292 Japan Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 1–1 Asahidai, Nomi, Ishikawa 923–1292, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. The present study explored a vast catalys space, comprising up to 14 elements - including Mg, Al, Cr, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ga, Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Ag, La, and Hf - co-supported on mesoporous silica, to discover effective combinations and understand the roles of each element in the production of 1,3-butadiene from ethanol. The discovered efficient catalysts were composed of primarily Mg, Zn, Y, and Hf, and secondary Zr, Nb, and La. Such highly multi-elemental design was suggested to achieve a balance for the complex reactions of ETB, where efficient conversion of acetaldehyde to butadiene while minimizing the production of ethylene was critical. The highest yield obtained was 71 ± 3% for butadiene. Through the application of machine learning techniques on the collected dataset, important insights related to catalyst design and catalysis were derived. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords High-throughput experimentation Ethanol valorization Butadiene Machine-learning Multi-element catalyst Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Innovation is inversely related to the maturity of the research in any discipline. The conventional methodology of empirically and sequentially testing a limited number of samples is time-consuming and highly suppositious. In contrast, the remarkable efficiency of high-throughput experimentation (HTE) provides for an alternative perspective outside the conventional practices as well as condensed experimental time to achieve systematic insights, leading to quicker discoveries [1]. The key advantages of process automation and parallelization can generate reliable and consistent datasets in a short time of period. One of the first outstanding instances of the systematic screening of libraries was the discovery of the first ammonia synthesis catalyst at BASF by Mittasch et al. in 1909. The pioneering work of J. J. Hanak questioning the approach of analyzing a single composition at a time led to the foundation of the modern-day HTE [2]. With time, this beneficial combinatorial approach to materials development and evaluation was adopted by many disciplines, such as heterogeneous catalysis [3]. HTE research accompanies three key challenges to be addressed, viz., experimental design, screening strategy, and data analysis. These challenges can be aptly addressed by the combination of existing knowledge and machine learning (ML) tools to narrow the parametric space as well as to avoid combinatorial explosion [4]. In general, ML has made tremendous impacts on the analyses of complex and bulky catalysis data including those generated by HTE [5,6]. It has helped researchers make catalyst discoveries through the building of predictive models for the target properties [6,7], and understand trends hidden in the data [8–10]. Moreover, the effective use of tools such as the genetic algorithm (GA) can assist in the exploration of a parametric space of catalysts, hereafter called catalyst space, to improve the probability of obtaining the best-performing catalysts [11]. As the name suggests, the GA is a search heuristic tool developed based on inspiration from Darwin’s theory of evolution. This is typically based on modification, selection, and survival of the fittest, leading to better adaption to a preset target. Previous reports from our group employed a random sampling strategy for exploring quaternary catalysts for oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) [8], followed by guiding subsequent catalyst design via MLs [10,12]. However, this strategy is not easily applicable for highly multi-dimensional catalyst design, such as 14 elemental catalysts studied in this article, where hitting high-performing catalysts by random sampling can be likened to searching a needle in the haystack. GA, on the other hand, facilitates the search for a highly multidimensional catalyst space by promoting the fittest catalysts. Some of the advantages of GA as compared to other optimization tools are 1) GA is applicable for exploring a highly multi-dimensional space without requiring prior knowledge and 2) optimization is done in parallel, fitting well within the HTE scheme. A major drawback of using any optimization tools in exploration is its data bias, leading to distortion in the analytical results. The conclusions obtained from GA are highly dependent on the input given and the conclusions obtained might not be universal but characteristic of that particular local maximum. However, this would not be a big issue, given that the goal of exploring a huge catalyst space is to discover high-performing catalysts. The conventional approach is time-consuming and expensive for augmenting the catalyst design and reaction conditions to enhance the yield and selectivity of the target chemicals. The combination of HTE with ML can defeat this challenge and is the way ahead to rapidly create and evaluate catalysts, leading to data-driven catalyst design. Our group has successfully demonstrated the use of the HTE-ML combination to design and evaluate the catalysts for oxidative coupling of methane, stabilizer formulation for improving polymeric material lifetime, etc [8,13,14]. Here, we report another successful implementation of the HTE-ML approach in the design, evolution, and evaluation of multi-element catalysts for ethanol to butadiene (ETB) conversion. The growing environmental concerns and public outcry across the world have motivated the search for alternative production pathways for basic chemicals from sustainable sources of carbon [15–17]. The valorization of biomass-based ethanol (EtOH) is attractive as it can be facilely converted to basic chemicals of industrial relevance such as acetaldehyde (AcH), ethylene, propylene, 1,3-butadiene (BD), isobutene, etc [18–20]. The demand for BD, which is critical in the production of synthetic rubber, adhesives, etc., is projected to reach 15 million metric tons in 2023 due to the explosive growth of the automobile industry [21,22]. The increasing imparity in its demand and supply beyond the capability of the conventional naphtha cracking has led researchers to explore and optimize the on-purpose production of BD [9,23]. Exploiting EtOH for the same comes with numerous advantages such as its increasing availability, industrialized production, investment, and good carbon economy [24,25]. ETB follows a complicated sequence of multiple steps, which can be achieved either by a one-step process developed by Lebedev or a two-step process developed by Ostromislensky [26]. The former process requires a higher temperature and a specific balance between EtOH and AcH to obtain a higher yield of BD. Whereas, the later process requires two reactors: one to convert EtOH to AcH and the other to transform a mixture of EtOH and previously produced AcH into BD. Both of the processes, however, follow the generally accepted mechanism referred to as the Toussaint-Kagan pathway as shown in Scheme 1 [27]. Since the first catalyst system, Al2O3/ZnO, developed by Lebedev in the 1930s, a myriad of catalysts have been proposed by many researchers [28]. These catalysts are predominantly based on mixed or supported oxides of early-to-late transition metal and lanthanide elements. In this study, we explored multi-element catalysts comprising up to 14 elements co-supported on mesoporous silica by means of GA-driven HTE. This approach allowed us to comprehensively address the complex ETB reaction pathway, where individual reactions are expected to be promoted by catalytic sites with varying natures [29,30]. This study involve the following steps: designing multi-element catalysts suitable to enhance the BD yield and selectivity, evaluating the prepared catalysts using an in-house designed HTE instrument, using the GA to evolve the catalysts based on the BD yields, and utilizing ML algorithms to extract catalytic trends from the obtained dataset. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O, CrCl3, Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, GaCl3, ZrCl4, MoCl5, and AgNO3 were purchased from FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical. Al(NO3)3·9 H2O and Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O were procured from Kanto Chemical. Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O, Y(NO3)3·6 H2O, NbCl5, La(NO3)3·6 H2O, and HfCl4 were purchased from Merck Sigma Aldrich. The Santo Barbara Amorphous 15 (SBA-15) of ACS Material was used as the sole catalyst support. DI water was used as the impregnation solvent for the nitrates, whereas ethanol (99.5%, FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical) was used for the chlorides. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Parallelized catalyst preparation based on two-step wet impregnation was carried out by using a Thermoscientific REACTI-THERM III #TS-18823 heating/stirring module. In the first step, the support powder (150 mg) was impregnated with an EtOH solution of the chlorides at 50 °C for 2 h. EtOH was removed under vacuum by centrifugal evaporation at 70 °C using a centrifugal evaporator (CVE-3100, Eyela). In the second step, the product of the first step was impregnated with an aqueous solution of the nitrates at 50 °C for 2 h. Water was removed by the same method at 90 °C. The dried products were subjected to calcination under air at 400 °C for 3 h in a muffle furnace to obtain multi-element catalysts. 2.3 Catalyst testing The catalysts were evaluated using an in-house designed HTE system illustrated in Fig. 1. This system contains an EtOH gasification unit, a gas flow distributor, an electric furnace holding 10 quartz reaction tubes with catalyst beds, an auto-sampler in tandem with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS, Transpector CPM 3, Inficon), and an exhaust system. All the lines in the HTE system are appropriately heated to prevent any condensation of the reactants and products. The EtOH gasification unit consists of a liquid mass flow controller (LMFC), a degasser, and a vaporizer that generates gasified EtOH under an argon (Ar) stream. The gas flow distributor affixed into a heating block then equally distributes the EtOH/Ar mixture into ten reaction tubes, which are fabricated by fusing two quartz tubes of inner diameters of 4 mm and 2 mm. As described in our previous work, this design allows us to minimize the gas phase reactions on the effluent side and maintains the inertness of the reactor walls at higher temperatures [8]. The catalyst bed of suitable height is affixed at the neck of the reaction tube using quartz wool. An electric furnace with three heating zones encompasses the reaction tubes ensuring uniform heating along the tubes. The effluent is then channeled into the sampling line of the autosampler, which is connected to a diaphragm pump and inlet of the QMS. The automation of sampling is achieved by means of programmed pneumatically actuated diaphragm valves (MEGA-ONE, Fujikin). During the sampling, the effluent continuously flows into the QMS, and mass spectra are recorded for the pre-set mass fragments. The measured intensities of the fragments are converted to relative pressures of individual gases using a scale factor obtained from external calibration. The unsampled fraction of the effluent is discharged through the exhaust system. Complete automation of the catalyst evaluation was achieved in the HTE system by programming the gas flow, reactor temperature, and auto-sampling of the effluents. The uniformity of gas flow across all the ten channels was validated and is presented in Fig. S1. The HTE instrument increases our ability manifold to evaluate catalysts and obtain datasets under various flow conditions and temperatures as compared to the conventional catalyst evaluation protocols. The catalysts filled into beds of 2.0 cm were subjected to the gas flow and temperature program depicted in Fig. 2. The program started with inline activation at 400 °C under O2, followed by testing under two gas flow conditions ( Q EtOH / Q Ar = 18.3/200.0 ccm/ccm = 0.09 and 35.6/200.0 ccm/ccm = 0.18) at five temperatures between 300 °C and 425 °C with 25 °C intervals. Note that the flow volumes refer to those before splitting into the 10 channels. The effluent from each reaction tube was sampled into QMS for 2.0 s for evaluation, followed by the evacuation of the sampling line for 12 s. This corresponds to 140 s per lap of sampling from 10 channels and about 20 mass spectra were recorded during each sampling. In this study, the products were dominantly comprised of BD, AcH, ethylene, butene, and unreacted EtOH. The EtOH conversion, and the yield and selectivity for the individual products were derived based on: (1) Conv EtOH % = P EtO H in − P EtO H out P EtO H in × 100 (2) Yield x % = P x P EtOH in × 100 (3) Selectivity x % = Yield x Conv EtOH × 100 where P EtO H in , out is the partial pressure of EtOH in the influent and effluent, respectively; P x is the partial pressure of the corresponding product x in the effluent. 2.4 Catalyst evolution Here, we utilized GA to explore multi-element catalysts, consisting of up to 14 elements including Mg, Al, Cr, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ga, Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Ag, La, and Hf, simultaneously supported on SBA-15. The selection of these elements was primarily based on their proven track record in ETB from literature. Each catalyst or each chromosome was represented by the total loading amount and the percentages of the individual elements within it. The total loading amount was restricted within 3.0 mmol per gram support. GA was initialized with a population of 20 catalysts whose genotype values were randomly determined. The catalysts were experimentally prepared and evaluated based on the methods described above. The fitness score was assigned to each catalyst using Eqs. 4 and 5, (4) f i = e 3 ρ i (5) ρ i = Yield BD , i − Yield BD , min Yield BD , max − Yield BD , min where f i corresponds to the fitness of the ith catalyst in the population. It is derived based on the corresponding BD yield standardized by the maximum and minimum BD yield in the population. In this study, each of the catalysts was evaluated under many different conditions and the best BD yield was almost exclusively obtained at 400 °C and 0.09 of P EtOH / P Ar ; hence the yield at this condition set was adopted to compute the fitness of each catalyst. A generational change was implemented by applying genetic operators such as crossover, mutation, random, and elitism. In the crossover, genotype values were randomly inherited from either of two selected parents, while the mutation was performed on one selected parent by changing the total loading between 1% and 100% with a 10% probability or by swapping the percentages of 2 randomly selected elements. The parents were selected based on the roulette method using the fitness score as a weight of the individuals. The random and elitism operators involve generating catalysts solely based on random numbers and preserving top-performing catalysts, respectively. Twelve children, two mutants, two randoms, and four elites, in total 20 catalysts, constitute the next generation. 2.5 Data analysis ML techniques were applied to the GA-derived dataset for extracting catalysis knowledge. Various regression algorithms such as lasso, ridge, support vector machine, random forest, and XGBoost were employed for the model building to predict the EtOH conversion and product yields. The dataset was split into 90% for training and 10% for testing. Hyperparameter tuning during the training was carried out by gridsearchCV with repeated 10-fold. In the context of prediction as well as obtaining feature importance, XGBoost regression was found to be the best choice in the current case based on its cross-validation (CV) score after the hyperparameter tuning. To gain insights into the importance of individual elements in determining the EtOH conversion and product yields, a Shapley analysis was applied to the regression model. These ML tasks were conducted using the scikit-learn package in Python. On the other hand, Gephi software was used to map the importance of elements in ETB and the composition-performance relationship of the catalysts. 3 Results and discussion In the literature, it has been reported that achieving optimal BD yield requires the presence of active sites that are uniformly distributed with the appropriate balance of acidity to promote all the reactions involved in ETB [31–33]. Additionally, other studies have demonstrated the use of two- or three-element catalysts to achieve this balance, albeit with only moderate BD yield and selectivity [27]. The present study, however, unlocks the potential of catalyst exploration within a vast catalyst space by utilizing GA-driven HTE. This top-down approach solves the challenge of optimizing the intricate reactions in a single-bed reactor by simultaneously optimizing the loading amounts of multiple elements onto the support. The catalyst space comprises elements known to catalyze EtOH dehydrogenation (Zn, Ag, Cu, Ni, Cr, Ga), aldol reaction (Mg, Zn, La, Hf, Y), MPV reaction (Mg, La, Y, Zr), and EtOH dehydration (Mo, Nb, Al) [15,29–31,33–36]. The choice of the supports is very crucial in determining the performance and sustenance of the catalysts. The high surface area as well as the large pore size of SBA-15 not only enhances the dispersion of the active sites but also prevents the deactivation of the catalysts due to coking [34]. In this study, a total of 276 catalysts were evaluated, which were distributed among 17 generations of GA and are listed in Table S1. The catalysts were evaluated in a uniform and process-consistent manner using the HTE instrument. Among the ten reaction condition sets tested, the temperature of 400 °C and the P EtOH / P Ar ratio of 0.09 predominantly yielded the highest BD yields (see Table S1). Accordingly, this particular condition set was used to determine the fitness of the catalysts in GA and for data analysis purposes. Fig. 3 displays the evolution of the catalysts in GA, tracking important performance metrics such as the EtOH conversion, the yield and selectivity for BD, as well as for major by-products, over the generations. The catalyst-wise data are shown in Fig. S2. In Fig. 3a, the average EtOH conversion was consistently above 80%, surpassing 90% in later generations. The product distribution underwent significant changes during the evolution process. Initially, the most common products were AcH and ethylene, followed by BD, while butene yields remained consistently low across all generations. The sum of these yields was nearly 100%, indicating the absence of other major by-products. The BD yield increased from about 22–33% on average during the first two generations. After a brief stagnation from the second to the fifth generation, the BD yield steadily increased, primarily due to the suppression of ethylene by-production, and secondly by the consumption of AcH. This fact suggests that components that promote EtOH dehydration were gradually replaced by those that convert AcH to BD. Eventually, the BD yield reached a generation average of about 50%. The best catalyst identified in this GA exhibited a BD yield of 73% with 77% selectivity (Fig. 3b). These results demonstrate the effectiveness of GA-driven HTE in discovering high-performing catalysts by exploring a highly multidimensional space. In Fig. 4a, the elemental distribution of the catalysts is averaged for each generation. Initially, the average loading of individual elements was similar due to random sampling. However, as the evolution proceeded, the average loading of Mg, Zn, Y, and Hf gradually increased and remained high until the final generation, indicating their importance for the ETB reaction. Conversely, the average loading of Ni, Al, and Cr decreased with the evolution of the catalysts. This study resulted in the discovery of 24 catalysts with a BD yield of 60% and above. Fig. 4b displays the elemental distribution of the top 20 catalysts, which were found to have similar but not identical compositions. These catalysts were primarily composed of Mg, Zn, Y, and Hf, with secondary elements like Zr, Nb, and La increasing when the loading of the four primary elements changed. The fraction of the other elements remained nearly constant for all 20 catalysts. Interestingly, the high-performing catalysts did not comprise only a few carefully chosen elements, but rather well-balanced mixtures of various elements. Although some might attribute these multi-element compositions to insufficient evolution in GA, the impressive performance of the catalysts suggests that such compositions are essential. It might be tempting to think that such multi-element compositions arose due to insufficient evolution in GA. However, given the remarkable performance of the obtained catalysts, it is more reasonable to acknowledge the essentiality of these multi-element compositions. Fig. 5 shows the temperature dependence of the EtOH conversion and the product yields for the top 20 catalysts at the P EtOH / P Ar ratio of 0.09. The temperature dependence was observed to be quite consistent among the catalysts: Increasing the temperature significantly promoted the EtOH conversion, exceeding 85% at 400 °C. At lower temperatures, the primary product formed was AcH, with its yield increasing slightly along with the EtOH conversion at higher temperatures before dropping at even higher temperatures mainly due to the BD formation. The BD yield increased substantially up to 400 °C but decreased at the highest temperature due to by-product formation such as ethylene and its oligomer. Indeed, the ethylene yield increased exponentially with increasing the temperature. These observations suggest that an ideal ETB catalyst can efficiently transform AcH into BD while minimizing residual AcH and inhibiting the ethylene formation. At higher EtOH concentration ( P EtOH / P Ar = 0.18), the temperature dependence was similar. However, to convert a larger quantity of AcH into BD, higher temperatures or longer contact times were required (Fig. S3). Due to the absence of the non-repeatability condition in the GA, 19 catalyst compositions were found to be repeatedly evaluated in the span of 17 generations of ETB catalysts. In most of the cases the BD yields were found to be very close to each other with a standard deviation of less than 5–6%. However, in very few cases this was found to be almost 12%. The deviation in the BD yields for catalysts with same composition can arise majorly due to the non-uniform distribution of the active sites over the surface of the support during their preparation. Even though the use of nitrate salts is attractive due to cost effectiveness, ease of availability, high degree of solubility, and facile decomposition, etc., nitrates of metals such as nickel, iron etc., lead to poor dispersion. This was attributed to the sharp increase in the viscosity of the precursor solution during the solvent removal preventing the effective redistribution of the active sites over the support. Few reports in the literature suggest that nitrate decomposition products can also affect the catalyst structure and thus its performance. Other experimental factors such as the catalyst bed height, QMS stability etc., contributes to the deviation in the BD yields. To validate and understand the source of deviation, two catalysts that were repeatedly evaluated were chosen (catalyst no: 237 & 255), prepared independently five times and evaluated. The validation results have been tabulated in table S2. For catalyst no 237, the average BD value (BDA) obtained by averaging the BD yields for this composition in the dataset reported is 66.5 ± 4.60 as compared to the BD value (BDv) obtained by averaging BD yields in the validation experiments of 71.2 ± 3.24. To understand the morphology and composition of the support and the catalyst, FESEM-EDS measurements were carried out. Fig. S4 shows the FESEM micrographs along with EDS mapping for the support along with fresh and spent samples of the catalyst with the best BD yield (catalyst 237). Though the morphology of the fresh as well as the spent catalysts did not change considerably as compared to the support, it was probably finer due to crushing during the catalyst preparation. The EDS measurements did not indicate any significant carbon deposition over the particles post evaluation indicating suppression of the side reaction and a facile conversion of EtOH to BD. Through GA, a relatively large and consistent catalyst dataset was obtained. This dataset was used to apply various regression methods, with the loading amounts of the individual elements as the explanatory variables and the BD yield as the target variable. The objective was to gain insights into the role of each element in the overall catalysis. After assessing various regression methods at their optimal hyperparameter sets in CV, XGBoost emerged as the most viable option, yielding r train 2 and r CV 2 values of 0.78 and 0.66, respectively. The best-fit model is shown in Fig. S4, which was not a perfect fit, but deemed sufficient for capturing the overall trend. This is due to the deviation in the BD yields for the catalyst with same composition in the dataset. The model was then subjected to the Shapley analysis, as it can capture trends in non-monotonic data, such as the current scenario. Figs. 6a and 6b show the Shapley analysis results for global and local feature importance, respectively. The SHAP value quantifies the contribution of each feature to the model prediction, so its interpretation reveals the impact of individual elements (their amounts) on the BD yield. The features are sorted according to their mean absolute SHAP value, which represents the order of importance of the elements in determining the BD yield. From Fig. 6a, Zn, Mo, Hf, Al, and Cr are seen to have the greatest impact among the 14 elements studied. In Fig. 6b, the SHAP summary plot shows the direction of the impact, with the x-axis indicating the SHAP value of individual data points and the color-axis denoting the loading amount of the corresponding elements. This plot clearly demonstrates the impact of each element's loading amount on the BD yield. To start, a higher loading amount of Zn has a positive impact on the BD yield, as indicated by the green-colored data points associated with positively large SHAP values. Conversely, a lower Zn loading is detrimental to the BD yield, as shown by the blue-colored data points with negatively large SHAP values corresponding to low feature values. Likewise, by combining Figs. 6a and 6b, it is possible to classify the elements as either positively important (Zn, Hf, Mg, Y, and Zr in descending order) or negatively important (Mo, Al, Cr, Ga, and Ag). The remaining four elements had low importance and were not interpreted. A similar Shapley analysis linked with XGBoost regression was performed for the EtOH conversion as well as for the yields of the other products (Fig. S5), allowing us to comprehensively understand the roles of the individual elements in the ETB catalysis. Here, we propose a method to visualize such a comprehensive understanding based on a force-directed network layout. More specifically, an elemental node and a performance metric node were linked according to the Shapley's global feature importance as determined in Fig. 6a and S5, where the larger the feature importance is, the more the two nodes attract with each other. The thickness of the edge linking the two nodes also represents the feature importance, while the edge color corresponds to the direction of the impact acquired from the local feature importance analysis of Fig. 6b and S5 (green: positive; blue: negative). This visualization shown in Fig. 7 gives us a wholesome understanding into the complex interplay between elements and reactions in ETB catalysis. At first glance, elements such as Zn, Hf, Mg and Y are found nearby the BD yield with the corresponding edge green-colored, indicating a strong positive impact. Among these, Hf and Y have a negative impact on the AcH yield, suggesting their role in converting AcH to butadiene. Zn, in contrast, has a positive impact on the AcH yield, consistent with its well-known role in converting EtOH into AcH. The elements such as Al, Mo, Nb, and Cu are positively related to the ethylene yield, so that they tended to be eliminated during the evolution (cf. Fig. 4). Thus, network visualization of Shapley’s feature importance helps to intuitively understand the catalytic roles of the individual elements. To understand the impact of each element not only qualitatively but also quantitatively, we implemented another type of network visualization, showing the relationship between the loading amount of each element and the BD yield. The method is similar to that described in our previous paper [37]. The loading amount of each element as well as the BD yield was divided into three classes - low (0–33%), med (34–67%) and high (68–100%) - based on the respective minimum and maximum values. Thus, each of the 276 catalysts obtained in GA was assigned compositional and performance labels. The association between the compositional and performance labels were counted over the 276 catalysts, which was used to construct a force-directed network, as shown in Fig. 8. It can be seen that medium to higher BD yields, above 30%, are achieved with catalysts that have higher or medium loadings of Zn, Hf, Y, Zr, and Mg, and lower loadings of the other elements. Conversely, higher loadings of Mo, Cr, Cu, and Al lead to lower BD yields. The integration of the XGBoost regression, Shapley analysis, and network visualization helped us gain deeper insights into the inter-elemental dependencies of various elements for the ETB catalysis. For instance, Vos et al. found that Zn suppresses the dehydration activity of Hf, which, on the other hand, has superior aldolization ability in silica-supported Zn-Hf catalysts [31]. Fujitani et al. reported that while Zn and Zr oxides can catalyze the ETB reaction independently, their combination can catalyze different rate-determining steps, thus synergistically promoting the ETB catalysis [32]. Additionally, the use of Cu/MCF in combination with Zr/MCF reduced the dehydration of EtOH and increased the selectivity towards BD [33]. Some elements needs assistance from other elements to promote the entire ETB reaction. Y, for example, was reported to exclusively catalyze the C-C bond formation between EtOH and AcH [15], whereas elements such as Zn, Hf, Zr, La, and Mg can catalyze more than one step in the ETB reaction. The interdependence between these elements arises from the complex reaction mechanism of ETB, and the literature studies mentioned above partially explain the significance of the co-presence of elements such as Zn, Hf, Y, Zr, and Mg in achieving higher BD yields. However, the current study is the first to explore the interdependence of 14 elements, which is significantly larger than the two or three elements discussed in the literature. Each of these elements plays a unique catalytic role in the complex mechanism of the ETB catalysis, allowing for fine-tuning of EtOH conversion and product distributions. This suggests that the methodology employed in this study can be effectively applied to other complex catalysis, similar to ETB. 4 Conclusions Multi-elemental catalyst design is an essential strategy for optimizing product distribution in complex catalysis. In this study, we aimed to explore a highly multidimensional catalyst space comprising up to 14 elements co-supported on mesoporous silica for ethanol to butadiene (ETB) catalysis using a genetic algorithm (GA)-driven high-throughput experimentation (HTE). Our objectives were to discover promising catalysts with superior yield and selectivity towards butadiene (BD), acquire a large and process-consistent catalyst dataset through HTE, and obtain insights into catalyst design and catalysis through data analysis. Key findings include: • Testing 276 catalysts generated by GA led to the discovery of many effective catalysts, with the best catalyst exhibiting a 71 ± 3% yield and 77% selectivity towards BD. • The effective catalysts primarily consisted of Mg, Zn, Y, and Hf, and secondarily of Zr, Nb, and La. The evolution reached such highly multi-element design, rather than selecting a few elements, suggesting the importance of a delicate inter-elemental balance for efficiently implementing ETB. • The effective catalysts efficiently converted formed acetaldehyde into BD while suppressing ethylene by-production. • The integrated use of XGBoost regression and Shapley’s feature importance analysis revealed the role of each element in the complex ETB catalysis. This was visualized based on a force-directed network layout for obtaining deeper insights. • Our findings suggest that the complex reaction mechanism of ETB favors interdependent actions of many elements to fine-tune product distribution. Overall, this study successfully demonstrated the promise of our highly multi-elemental approach, not only for catalyst discovery but also for understanding complex catalysis such as ETB. coredata.dc:description: The present study explored a vast catalys space, comprising up to 14 elements - including Mg, Al, Cr, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ga, Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Ag, La, and Hf - co-supported on mesoporous silica, to discover effective combinations and understand the roles of each element in the production of 1,3-butadiene from ethanol. The discovered efficient catalysts were composed of primarily Mg, Zn, Y, and Hf, and secondary Zr, Nb, and La. Such highly multi-elemental design was suggested to achieve a balance for the complex reactions of ETB, where efficient conversion of acetaldehyde to butadiene while minimizing the production of ethylene was critical. The highest yield obtained was 71 ± 3% for butadiene. Through the application of machine learning techniques on the collected dataset, important insights related to catalyst design and catalysis were derived.
coredata.dc:title: Exploration of ethanol-to-butadiene catalysts by high-throughput experimentation and machine learning
